key_points: 2021 was marked by highly aggressive ransomware attacks targeting critical infrastructure, healthcare, and education.
The Colonial Pipeline attack in May shut down a major fuel pipeline on the East Coast, leading to widespread fuel shortages.
Colonial Pipelines paid a ransom of 75 bitcoins (over $4 million) to the Russia-linked DarkSide gang, but law enforcement later recovered part of the funds.
The compromise of Kaseya's VSA tool by REvil ransomware gang affected around 1,500 organizations worldwide.
Twitch experienced a major breach in October, with 128 GB of data, including source codes and streamer revenue information, being leaked.
The Hafnium group exploited Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerabilities, affecting tens of thousands of entities globally.
NSO Group faced lawsuits from WhatsApp and Apple for creating spyware used by autocratic governments for targeted surveillance.
JBS SA, the world's largest meat processing company, was hit by a ransomware attack affecting its North American and Australian IT systems.
Accellion's patching of vulnerabilities was too slow, leading to data breaches and extortion attempts impacting multiple organizations.
The events of 2021 highlighted the continued and increasing threats of cyberattacks, prompting calls for more comprehensive action by governments.
spokespersons: John Scott-Railton (Senior Researcher, University of Toronto's Citizen Lab)
